figure.name: architecture description terms

term.name: architecture
term.definition: <system> fundamental concepts or properties of a system in its environment ( REF idBCD10BE481B544698858512B057E1D40 ) embodied in its elements ( REF idA9454DB86F4C47c9902B7ABEE2462EA8 ), relationships, and in the principles of its design and evolution \r\n

term.name: architecture description
term.definition: work product used to express an architecture ( REF id1977CCC04EA948719638C89546E52E47 ) \r\n

term.name: architecture framework
term.definition: conventions, principles and practices for the description of architectures ( REF id1977CCC04EA948719638C89546E52E47 ) established within a specific domain of application and/or community of stakeholders \r\n
term.example: Generalised Enterprise Reference Architecture and Methodologies (GERAM) [ISO 15704] is an architecture framework.
Reference Model of Open Distributed Processing (RM-ODP) [ISO/IEC 10746] is an architecture framework.

term.name: architecture model
term.definition: work product representing one or more architecture views ( REF idBD7658051DA3495bA45E71D438FCD3DF ) and expressed in a format governed by a model kind ( REF id539D69676C04491081CB654FB9B87320 )\r\n

term.name: architecture view
term.definition: work product expressing the architecture ( REF id1977CCC04EA948719638C89546E52E47 ) of a system from the perspective of specific system concerns ( REF idFA25496536F542ee8EEECAE2225A828E ) \r\n

term.name: architecture viewpoint
term.definition: work product establishing the conventions for the construction, interpretation and use of architecture views ( REF idBD7658051DA3495bA45E71D438FCD3DF ) to frame specific system concerns ( REF idFA25496536F542ee8EEECAE2225A828E ) \r\n

term.name: concern
term.definition: <system> interest in a system relevant to one or more of its stakeholders ( REF id730A631B2F0A43c2870FF7EC89013DA2 )
term.note: A concern pertains to any influence on a system in its environment, including developmental, technological, business, operational, organizational, political, economic, legal, regulatory, ecological and social influences.

term.name: element
term.definition: <architecture> component member of an architecture ( REF id1977CCC04EA948719638C89546E52E47 )

term.name: environment
term.definition: <system> <font color="#313131">context determining the setting and circumstances of all influences upon a system</font>
term.note: The environment of a system includes developmental, technological, business, operational, organizational, political, economic, legal, regulatory, ecological and social influences.

term.name: model kind
term.definition: conventions for a type of modelling
term.note: Examples of model kinds include data flow diagrams, class diagrams, Petri nets, balance sheets, organization charts and state transition models.

term.name: stakeholder
term.definition: <system> individual, team, organization, or classes thereof, having an interest in a system \r\n

term.name: system
term.definition: combination of interacting elements organized to achieve one or more stated purposes

figure.name: generic service terms

term.name: consumer
term.definition: entity ( REF id040D6A1B412A4cc6921882357A58F747 ) that has a need ( REF id8C060C793CE14fb88B50E52BD3A3FDE6 ) to be fulfilled

term.name: entity
term.definition: concrete or abstract thing that exists, did exist, or might exist, including associations among these things
term.example: A person, object, event, idea, process, etc.

term.name: need
term.definition: factor or condition necessary to achieve desired results within a specified context of use

term.name: service
term.definition: performance of one or more tasks or provision of one or more facilities to enable one or more tasks for a consumer ( REF id8B698530E3B946b3B78C2E6C58FE87D7 ) to fulfil a need ( REF id8C060C793CE14fb88B50E52BD3A3FDE6 )

term.name: service provider
term.definition: entity ( REF id040D6A1B412A4cc6921882357A58F747 ) that delivers one or more services ( REF id1C826F4DC7744eb7B8DDB33EF68A28F5 )

figure.name: ITS service terms

term.name: service
term.definition: <ITS> performance of one or more tasks that fulfils an ITS user need ( REF idC312FB0B6C1140db86F158458C5AC4B8 ) for an ITS user ( REF idF263D8B81E914fcf9B8287F21A9C2350 )

term.name: service provider
term.definition: <ITS> entity ( REF id040D6A1B412A4cc6921882357A58F747 ) that delivers one or more ITS services ( REF id4D485872E9EE414e9CE1AB855A03540B )

term.name: user
term.definition: <ITS> entity ( REF id040D6A1B412A4cc6921882357A58F747 ) that has an ITS user need ( REF idC312FB0B6C1140db86F158458C5AC4B8 ) to be fulfilled

term.name: user need
term.definition: <ITS> need ( REF id8C060C793CE14fb88B50E52BD3A3FDE6 ) of an entity external to the intelligent transport system for a surface transport system ( REF id261629D58D7B439b8DAE5905D2EEF4D5 ) benefit that can be met with the use of a technology system ( REF id03252B24F74349ac87D95187F13128C7 )

figure.name: ITS-S service terms

term.name: bounded, secured, managed domain
term.definition: controlled processing environment that adheres to a minimum set of management and security principles and procedures so as to establish a level of trust between itself and other similar ITS stations ( REF idF1E402D380EE478c957A2FF53D9EA0C5 ) with which it might communicate

term.name: service
term.definition: <ITS-S> performance of one or more tasks that fulfils an ITS-S user need ( REF idAE2F5ED40F9549e2A07B4C547A3C4CF4 ) for an ITS-S user ( REF idFFC4D737010249d0B062A188246E1DAD )

term.name: service provider
term.definition: <ITS-S> ITS-S ( REF idF1E402D380EE478c957A2FF53D9EA0C5 ) that delivers one or more ITS-S services ( REF idED2A90BFB7F249ffBB47A5827835D6E0 )\r\n

term.name: user
term.definition: <ITS-S> entity ( REF id040D6A1B412A4cc6921882357A58F747 ) that has an ITS-S user need ( REF idAE2F5ED40F9549e2A07B4C547A3C4CF4 )

term.name: user need
term.definition: <ITS-S> need ( REF id8C060C793CE14fb88B50E52BD3A3FDE6 ) for processing within a bounded, secure, managed domain ( REF id866BE3730A304564BBC18CA138D01808 )

figure.name: ITS-S communication service terms

term.name: communication need
term.definition: <ITS-S> need ( REF id8C060C793CE14fb88B50E52BD3A3FDE6 ) for communication functionality that connects an ITS-S ( REF idF1E402D380EE478c957A2FF53D9EA0C5 ) to other nodes\r\n

term.name: communication process
term.definition: <ITS-S> entity ( REF id040D6A1B412A4cc6921882357A58F747 ) that delivers one or more ITS-S communication services ( REF id04F387DD652043039464AA4FA280AB16 )

term.name: communication service
term.definition: <ITS-S> performance of one or more tasks that fulfils an ITS-S communication need ( REF id202B9BA1EA2F4bfbA3D5BE04ACA3E2D5 ) for an ITS-S communication user ( REF id1FC1FE8C6F1A41a7AECE0F7A9C874620 )\r\n

term.name: communication user
term.definition: <ITS-S> entity ( REF id040D6A1B412A4cc6921882357A58F747 ) that has an ITS-S communication need ( REF id202B9BA1EA2F4bfbA3D5BE04ACA3E2D5 )

figure.name: system terms

term.name: cooperative ITS
term.definition: subset of ITS ( REF id95C4A86465B74046823106670EF95C77 ) where information is shared among physical objects ( REF id8EA65F2D6F6347bf8FF4C5CD35C61C68 ) based on mutual security agreements with a credentialing system
term.note: Most current-day computer systems rely upon an agreement between the owners or users of the two systems involved in an exchange. For example, there is typically bi-lateral agreement between a provider and a user. C-ITS instead relies upon a system of third-party agreements. In other words, a third party defines the rules for operating within a domain and creates a trust network. Providers and users establish agreements with the third party agreeing to abide by the rules. Providers and users then directly interact based on the rules of the trust network without requiring any direct relationship between the two.

C-ITS does not preclude two parties from having a separate bi-lateral agreement, but any services requiring a bi-lateral agreement would not technically be considered "C-ITS". For example, two emergency vehicles may have a bi-lateral agreement to share incident information containing sensitive data; such a service would not be considered C-ITS, since it is under a bi-lateral agreement. However, the same two vehicles may share vehicle location and motion information for collision avoidance purposes; this would be considered C-ITS since the agreement to share that information is under the broader use case that uses a third-party agreement.

term.name: intelligent transport system
term.definition: technology system ( REF id03252B24F74349ac87D95187F13128C7 ) that is designed to benefit a surface transport system ( REF id261629D58D7B439b8DAE5905D2EEF4D5 )
term.note: There is not complete agreement on the precise limits of ITS. Currently, the term is almost exclusively applied to ground-based travel of goods and people over significant distances. The term is viewed as including ferry systems, which often form an integral part of a local surface transport system; it is less clear if it includes long-distance sea-fairing ships. ITS is also generally applied to transport systems that cover a considerable distance (e.g., control systems for factory conveyance technologies are not often referred to as “ITS”). Some have suggested that air travel, which is arguably a transport system designed to move physical entities between points on the surface of the earth, should be included in the scope of the term, but this perspective is not universally accepted. It is expected that the exact limits of the term will be further refined as the technology matures.
Benefits potentially include, but are not limited to, increased safety, sustainability, efficiency, and comfort.

The long form (i.e., "intelligent transport system") is often used when the noun is used as a subject, whereas the abbreviation (i.e., "ITS") is often used to modify another noun (e.g., “Intelligent transport systems provide ITS services.”).

term.name: surface transport system
term.definition: transport system ( REF id8648D088383A40a19D19B3E02A7060DF ) designed to move physical entities across the surface of the earth
term.note: A surface transport system might include tunnels, bridges, and similar elements.

term.name: technology system
term.definition: system ( REF id9F9DE40282B84b8aAD4F618C7836F09E ) that is comprised of information, communication, sensor, and control technologies

term.name: transport system
term.definition: system ( REF id9F9DE40282B84b8aAD4F618C7836F09E ) of infrastructure elements and optionally vehicles ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) that jointly are designed to move entities ( REF id040D6A1B412A4cc6921882357A58F747 ) from an origin to a destination
term.note: Transport systems are not necessarily limited to the transport of physical entities; the Internet could be considered a transport system of electronic entities.

figure.name: documentation terms

term.name: scenario
term.definition: <use case> a description of the sequence of events from the user’s perspective to perform a task in a specified context\r\n
term.source: ISO/IEC 25062:2006(en), A.17, added the context of a use case

term.name: use case
term.definition: description of the behavioural requirements of a system and its interaction with a user\r\n

figure.name: architecture view terms

term.name: communications view
term.definition: architecture view ( REF idBD7658051DA3495bA45E71D438FCD3DF ) from the communications viewpoint ( REF idFA802A0C473248fc9F50178DD38C56D8 )
term.note: Within ITS, the preferred model for describing the communications view is based on the ITS-S reference architecture.

term.name: communications viewpoint
term.definition: architecture viewpoint ( REF id2D6E2A89A52E4a689CD868265F24A29E ) used to frame communication interface concerns, including all layers of the OSI stack and related management and security issues\r\n

term.name: enterprise view
term.definition: architecture view ( REF idBD7658051DA3495bA45E71D438FCD3DF ) from the enterprise viewpoint ( REF idF107015E884048deAC7C651CBC4B8420 )

term.name: enterprise viewpoint
term.definition: architecture viewpoint ( REF id2D6E2A89A52E4a689CD868265F24A29E ) used to frame the policies, funding incentives, working arrangements, and jurisdictional structure that support the technical layers of the architecture\r\n

term.name: functional view
term.definition: architecture view ( REF idBD7658051DA3495bA45E71D438FCD3DF ) from the functional viewpoint ( REF id44BCE17E4D7F4e10AEBDA4BEA9679B0E )

term.name: functional viewpoint
term.definition: architecture viewpoint ( REF id2D6E2A89A52E4a689CD868265F24A29E ) used to frame the functionality concerns, including the definition of processes that perform transport functions and data flows shared between these processes\r\n

term.name: physical view
term.definition: architecture view ( REF idBD7658051DA3495bA45E71D438FCD3DF ) from the physical viewpoint ( REF idAB7049839C6D4f60BC7472FCFED26DB4 )
term.note: The term "deployment view" is sometimes used within the broader ICT community, but the term "physical view" is preferred to prevent confusion between the physical view of a reference architecture and any part of a deployment architecture.

term.name: physical viewpoint
term.definition: architecture viewpoint ( REF id2D6E2A89A52E4a689CD868265F24A29E ) used to frame system engineering concerns, including the assignment of functionality to physical objects ( REF id8EA65F2D6F6347bf8FF4C5CD35C61C68 ) and the interfaces among these physical objects\r\n

figure.name: Communication view terms

term.name: access layer
term.definition: part of the data plane ( REF id13CDCB9D95E24ff1B8C47DDF63A55303 ) that provides the functionality related to the physical and data link layers of the open systems interconnect (OSI) reference model
term.note: Within the IETF, the term "link layer" is used to describe the same functionality as the ITS-S reference architecture access layer.
Within the US, the NTCIP standards use the term "subnet layer" to describe the same functionality as the ITS-S reference architecture.

term.name: application entity
term.definition: part of the ITS station reference architecture ( REF idCAC31494A311430cBB567F2A82C166EC ) that is responsible for providing ITS-related functionality
term.note: Within the US, the NTCIP standards identify an "information layer" on top of the traditional OSI stack; however, the purpose of this layer includes both information configuration and functionality. The ITS-S reference architecture separates these two roles between the management entity and the application entity.

term.name: data plane
term.definition: part of the ITS station reference architecture ( REF idCAC31494A311430cBB567F2A82C166EC ) that is responsible for handling communications with other physical objects ( REF id8EA65F2D6F6347bf8FF4C5CD35C61C68 )

term.name: facilities layer
term.definition: part of the data plane ( REF id13CDCB9D95E24ff1B8C47DDF63A55303 ) that provides the functionality related to the session, presentation, and application layers of the open systems interconnect (OSI) reference model\r\n
term.note: Within the US, the NTCIP standards call the facilities layer the "application layer"; however, as this term is easily confused with both the OSI application layer and the application entity, the term should be avoided.

term.name: management entity
term.definition: part of the ITS station reference architecture ( REF idCAC31494A311430cBB567F2A82C166EC ) that is responsible for management of communications and configuration information for the local physical object ( REF id8EA65F2D6F6347bf8FF4C5CD35C61C68 ) and possibly remote physical objects

term.name: security entity
term.definition: part of the ITS station reference architecture ( REF idCAC31494A311430cBB567F2A82C166EC ) that is responsible for providing privacy, communication security, and system security

term.name: transnet layer
term.definition: part of the data plane ( REF id13CDCB9D95E24ff1B8C47DDF63A55303 ) that provides the functionality related to the network and transport layers of the open systems interconnect (OSI) reference model\r\n
term.note: The full name of this layer is the networking and transport layer, but the term transnet layer provides a more concise name.

figure.name: Enterprise view terms

term.name: document
term.definition: uniquely identified unit of information for human use
term.note: A document can be a single information item, or part of a larger information item.
term.example: A report, specification, manual, or book, in printed or electronic form.

term.name: enterprise object
term.definition: element ( REF idA9454DB86F4C47c9902B7ABEE2462EA8 ) within an enterprise view ( REF id4C3EDEBD6786459a8343C1B09B870255 ) that represents an organization or individual

term.name: extends
term.definition: <enterprise view> relationship ( REF id15042ADE65AA448a98FF7ECFA044549B ) where one resource ( REF id55BD7B9720A44728AE93ED1F75D7692B ) supplements another resource
term.example: A functional object might extend the functionality of another functional object.

term.name: formal coordination
term.definition: <enterprise view> interaction ( REF id266739C36D20412dBADD84864A84FB14 ) between two enterprise objects ( REF idFE675C964126463bBB0CAB673DBFF9C7 ) governed by a documented agreement
term.example: A roadway operator might enter into formal agreement(s) with the owner of a roadway and the owner(s) of the associated roadway equipment.

term.name: includes
term.definition: <enterprise view> relationship ( REF id15042ADE65AA448a98FF7ECFA044549B ) where one resource ( REF id55BD7B9720A44728AE93ED1F75D7692B ) contains another resource
term.example: Every ITS component includes one or more functional objects.

term.name: informal coordination
term.definition: <enterprise view> interaction ( REF id266739C36D20412dBADD84864A84FB14 ) between two enterprise objects ( REF idFE675C964126463bBB0CAB673DBFF9C7 ) governed by an understanding that is not documented in a formal agreement between the two parties
term.example: A pedestrian might reasonably expect that the roadway operator will provide a safe environment even though there is no direct formal agreement between the pedestrian and roadway operator.

term.name: interaction
term.definition: <enterprise view> element ( REF idA9454DB86F4C47c9902B7ABEE2462EA8 ) that represents coordination between two enterprise objects ( REF idFE675C964126463bBB0CAB673DBFF9C7 )\r\n

term.name: relationship
term.definition: <enterprise view> element ( REF idA9454DB86F4C47c9902B7ABEE2462EA8 ) that represents an association between two resources ( REF id55BD7B9720A44728AE93ED1F75D7692B )

term.name: resource
term.definition: <enterprise view> element ( REF idA9454DB86F4C47c9902B7ABEE2462EA8 ) that represents an entity that is related to an enterprise object

term.name: role
term.definition: <enterprise view> element ( REF idA9454DB86F4C47c9902B7ABEE2462EA8 ) that represents the association between an enterprise object ( REF idFE675C964126463bBB0CAB673DBFF9C7 ) and another enterprise view element
term.example: A driver operates a vehicle.

figure.name: functional view terms

term.name: data flow
term.definition: representation of data flowing between two processes ( REF id6DD0743FF44F4f0e9817C766379AD954 ) or between a process and a terminator ( REF id98ACC203E1E34474AF1A04245619E6BF )

term.name: process
term.definition: <functional view> function or activity required to support an ITS service ( REF id4D485872E9EE414e9CE1AB855A03540B )

term.name: process specification
term.definition: document ( REF id4D42D0BA04584798BEB7CFD665901F33 ) that defines a lowest-level process ( REF id6DD0743FF44F4f0e9817C766379AD954 )

figure.name: physical view terms

term.name: functional object
term.definition: group of similar system processes ( REF id6DD0743FF44F4f0e9817C766379AD954 ) from the functional view ( REF id9835C11FD8C04296807C2D9A60453679 ) of the architecture ( REF id1977CCC04EA948719638C89546E52E47 ) that are jointly assigned to a physical object ( REF id8EA65F2D6F6347bf8FF4C5CD35C61C68 ) in the physical view ( REF idB34FD020963F4c85BD2610D158A905D2 ).
term.example: A vehicle OBE might include a "vehicle basic safety" functional object.

term.name: information flow
term.definition: information that is exchanged between physical objects ( REF id8EA65F2D6F6347bf8FF4C5CD35C61C68 )\r\n

term.name: information triple
term.definition: information flow ( REF id752D601C79B54677BF47786D7FA84DBF ) from a physical object ( REF id8EA65F2D6F6347bf8FF4C5CD35C61C68 ) acting as an information source and sent to another physical object ( REF id8EA65F2D6F6347bf8FF4C5CD35C61C68 ) acting as an information sink\r\n

term.name: ITS component
term.definition: physical object ( REF id3783095C41E041c8B0CC1813CBCAEE44 ) that has been assigned one or more ITS functional objects ( REF idEC65B14A2BF845deBCC48632F635C9FF )\r\n
term.note: Physical objects are ITS components if they are an integral part of the system; otherwise they are terminators.

term.name: physical object
term.definition: element ( REF idA9454DB86F4C47c9902B7ABEE2462EA8 ) within the physical view ( REF idB34FD020963F4c85BD2610D158A905D2 ) of an ITS architecture ( REF idAEDCDFD1175A4735AF8F91068BE5703F ) that represents a physical entity that interacts with other physical entities in the provision of ITS services ( REF id4D485872E9EE414e9CE1AB855A03540B )\r\n
term.note: WIthin many ITS reference architectures, physical objects are placed into one of five categories: centre, support, field, vehicle, or traveller.

term.name: terminator
term.definition: physical object ( REF id8EA65F2D6F6347bf8FF4C5CD35C61C68 ) that represents an external user of ITS ( REF id95C4A86465B74046823106670EF95C77 )\r\n

figure.name: architecture type terms

term.name: C-ITS reference architecture
term.definition: reference architecture ( REF id7823F79833D54238B649F8A4D20F13C5 ) for one or more ITS services ( REF id4D485872E9EE414e9CE1AB855A03540B ) where each service requires at least one C-ITS data exchange

term.name: deployment architecture
term.definition: architecture ( REF id1977CCC04EA948719638C89546E52E47 ) that provides a vision of a specific deployment of a system within a geographic area

term.name: ITS deployment architecture
term.definition: deployment architecture ( REF id78E7722880BD47d7BEB75B27B5842A74 ) for one or more ITS services ( REF id4D485872E9EE414e9CE1AB855A03540B )

term.name: ITS planning architecture
term.definition: planning architecture ( REF id0875724C4E4C4527A11C1B5977FA6250 ) for one or more ITS services ( REF id4D485872E9EE414e9CE1AB855A03540B )

term.name: ITS reference architecture
term.definition: reference architecture ( REF id7823F79833D54238B649F8A4D20F13C5 ) for one or more ITS services ( REF id4D485872E9EE414e9CE1AB855A03540B )\r\n
term.note: An ITS architecture might be a reference, planning, or deployment architecture.
The Harmonised Architecture Reference for Technical Standards (HARTS; http://htg7.org) is an example of an ITS reference architecture.

term.name: ITS-S reference architecture
term.definition: reference architecture ( REF id7823F79833D54238B649F8A4D20F13C5 ) for handling communications within a physical object ( REF id8EA65F2D6F6347bf8FF4C5CD35C61C68 ) as defined in ISO 21217
term.note: The ITS-S reference architecture is the preferred model for describing communication designs for information exchanges between physical objects, even if the design does not meet the minimum requirements for an ITS station. For example, the ITS-S reference architecture can be used to describe a communications stack that does not provide a bounded, secured, managed domain; however an implementation of such a design would not be an ITS station.

term.name: planning architecture
term.definition: architecture ( REF id1977CCC04EA948719638C89546E52E47 ) that provides a long-term vision of system elements ( REF idA9454DB86F4C47c9902B7ABEE2462EA8 ) that may be deployed and managed by different projects and/or entities within a geographic area
term.note: Some countries use the term "regional architecture", but in international standards, the term "regional" is avoided due to its multiple meanings.

term.name: reference architecture
term.definition: template solution for an architecture ( REF id1977CCC04EA948719638C89546E52E47 ) for a particular domain
term.note: Interface standards are based on a reference architecture, which should be explicitly described.
term.source: Wikipedia the free encyclopedia – definition of reference architecture [Internet]. [cited 2018 Jul 17]; Available from: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/reference_architecture

figure.name: data concept management terms

term.name: data concept
term.definition: entity that refers to an abstraction or thing in the natural world that can be identified with explicit boundaries and meaning and whose properties and behaviour all follow the same rules\r\n
term.note: Data concepts can be classified into the following types: object class, value domain, data element, aggregate domain, data frame, message, interface dialogue, dictionary document, or module

term.name: data concept registry
term.definition: electronic data dictionary ( REF idB06371D38EFC48e299F50E38BFECA3F5 ) that follows precise documented rules for the registration and management of stored data concepts ( REF id5C989C1352B14d07BB1E631FC7D46F8F ); it typically also includes advanced features for adding, retrieving, and working with its contents
term.note: The data concept registry contains meta-attributes about data concepts in terms of their names and representational forms as well as the semantics associated with the data concepts. A data concept registry may contain data that assists information interchange and re-use, both from the perspective of human users and for machine-interpretation of data concepts.

term.name: data dictionary
term.definition: listing of data concepts ( REF id5C989C1352B14d07BB1E631FC7D46F8F ) and their meta-attributes in a consistent format

term.name: meta-attribute
term.definition: documenting characteristic of a data concept ( REF id5C989C1352B14d07BB1E631FC7D46F8F ) that is stored in a data dictionary ( REF idB06371D38EFC48e299F50E38BFECA3F5 )

figure.name: data concept type terms

term.name: aggregate domain
term.definition: data concept ( REF id5C989C1352B14d07BB1E631FC7D46F8F ) that defines a grouping of data elements ( REF id6ADFFDA7618A4047AE100991CBCE83C7 ) and/or data frames ( REF idD0B512E1030A4b998CB13473D336CBFC ) \r\n

term.name: data element
term.definition: data concept ( REF id5C989C1352B14d07BB1E631FC7D46F8F ) represented by a specific value domain ( REF idACC1C171626D40479E3CC4C273BEA796 ) and that describes a single atomic property about an object class ( REF idDF674EF5FB8049aaBE03DC6E5FF03853 ).
term.note: A data element is composed of an object class, a property of the represented object class and a value domain.

term.name: data frame
term.definition: data concept ( REF id5C989C1352B14d07BB1E631FC7D46F8F ) represented by a specific aggregate domain ( REF id3885C6F4DEBA4ad3952CF6E500F10712 ) and that describes information of interest through a useful grouping of more atomic properties about one or more object classes ( REF idDF674EF5FB8049aaBE03DC6E5FF03853 ).
term.note: The grouping may be a set, sequence, or a choice.

term.name: interface dialogue
term.definition: data concept ( REF id5C989C1352B14d07BB1E631FC7D46F8F ) that defines bi-directional communication sequence between two parties in accordance with predetermined protocols\r\n

term.name: message
term.definition: data concept ( REF id5C989C1352B14d07BB1E631FC7D46F8F ) that is a grouping of data elements ( REF id6ADFFDA7618A4047AE100991CBCE83C7 ), data frames ( REF idD0B512E1030A4b998CB13473D336CBFC ), or data elements ( REF id6ADFFDA7618A4047AE100991CBCE83C7 ) and data frames ( REF idD0B512E1030A4b998CB13473D336CBFC ) that is used to convey a complete set of information

term.name: object class
term.definition: description of a set of objects that share the same properties, relationships, and semantics
term.note: Adapted from ISO/IEC 11179-1:2013; an object class is conceptually similar to an ISO/IEC 11179 object, but it does not include operations or methods and ISO/IEC 11179 "attributes" are called "properties" in this International Standard.

term.name: value domain
term.definition: data concept ( REF id5C989C1352B14d07BB1E631FC7D46F8F ) that defines a set of permissible values\r\n

figure.name: ITS service implementation terms

term.name: application template
term.definition: <ITS> executable technical pattern of an ITS application specification ( REF id4D636FF9C4F84e41B76850FC248B4D99 )

term.name: interoperability design
term.definition: characteristics necessary to fully define how various physical objects ( REF id8EA65F2D6F6347bf8FF4C5CD35C61C68 ) interoperate to provide a service ( REF id1C826F4DC7744eb7B8DDB33EF68A28F5 )\r\n
term.note: Characteristics often include but are not limited to functional, performance, and interface requirements.

term.name: ITS application
term.definition: interoperability design ( REF id573047514B814efe85FCFA271736EE72 ) for an ITS service ( REF id4D485872E9EE414e9CE1AB855A03540B )

term.name: ITS application specification
term.definition: one or more documents that detail all necessary requirements for an ITS application ( REF id1A22C407CEBA41c495E1D89FC4C87504 )\r\n

term.name: ITS deployment
term.definition:
installation capable of implementing one or more ITS applications ( REF id1A22C407CEBA41c495E1D89FC4C87504 )\r\n
\r\n
term.note: An ITS deployment typically refers to the support, central and roadside ITS stations coupled with a tacit acknowledgement of the mobile ITS stations that will communicate with the support, central, or roadside ITS stations.

term.name: ITS implementation
term.definition: integration of each physical object ( REF id8EA65F2D6F6347bf8FF4C5CD35C61C68 ) necessary to implement one or more ITS applications ( REF id1A22C407CEBA41c495E1D89FC4C87504 )
term.note: An ITS application typically requires multiple components (e.g., a ITS-S acting as a user and another ITS-S acting as a provider). An ITS implementation includes a sample of each component necessary for the service but often does not represent a complete deployment.
An ITS implementation is typically used for a laboratory or other experimental environment prior to a full-scale deployment.

figure.name: Concept model for ITS-S service implementation terms

term.name: ITS-S application
term.definition: ITS-S application process ( REF id371D609484264a3598C7092967DD21DD ) within the application entity ( REF idB67D64896F6943cc98608CF4BB934A7D )

term.name: ITS-S application implementation
term.definition: ITS-S application process implementation ( REF id1B8E2BF498F44b69A2DDCC37CFA527AA ) within the application entity ( REF idB67D64896F6943cc98608CF4BB934A7D )

term.name: ITS-S application installation
term.definition: ITS-S application process installation ( REF idA70703E708334662A8EDA8C71037BAE7 ) within the application entity ( REF idB67D64896F6943cc98608CF4BB934A7D )

term.name: ITS-S application instance
term.definition: ITS-S application process instance ( REF id21D89F0DC3D74be1A2393C913221D4D2 ) within the application entity ( REF idB67D64896F6943cc98608CF4BB934A7D )

term.name: ITS-S application process
term.definition: element in an ITS station ( REF idF1E402D380EE478c957A2FF53D9EA0C5 ) that performs information processing for an ITS-S service ( REF idED2A90BFB7F249ffBB47A5827835D6E0 )\r\n

term.name: ITS-S application process implementation
term.definition: implementation of an ITS-S application process ( REF id371D609484264a3598C7092967DD21DD )
term.note: A unique implementation is typically associated with an implementation name, a version, and release number.

term.name: ITS-S application process installation
term.definition: installation of an ITS-S application process implementation ( REF id1B8E2BF498F44b69A2DDCC37CFA527AA )\r\n
term.note: A unique installation is typically associated with a specific license code or serial number.

term.name: ITS-S application process instance
term.definition: run-time instance of an ITS-S application process installation ( REF idA70703E708334662A8EDA8C71037BAE7 )\r\n

figure.name: roadway component terms

term.name: carriageway
term.definition: contiguous width of roadway ( REF id3F880EDEBFE84014A43B46167936F4B1 )
term.note: A carriageway is comprised of one or more travel lanes (i.e., the travelled way) and may include shoulders and lay-bys.
When looking at a cross-section of the right-of-way, the roadway consists of all of the carriageways and carriageways are separated by physical barriers.

term.name: dual carriageway
term.definition: roadway ( REF id3F880EDEBFE84014A43B46167936F4B1 ) comprised of exactly two carriageways ( REF id855CC715739D462e9790E893914D8768 )
term.note: The two carriageways are typically designed for travel in opposite directions.

term.name: easement
term.definition: stretch of land reserved for transportation purposes
term.note: The easement includes all carriageways as well as a significant width to allow for roadside devices, clearance zones, sidewalks, drainage facilities, sound walls, etc.
This concept is sometimes referred to as "right-of-way"; however, the preferred meaning of "right-of-way" is to identify which vehicle has the legal authority to access a portion of roadway.

term.name: lane
term.definition: portion of easement ( REF idF9F0ACCE2D49434a803C0D87211F753A )intended for a specific purpose along its length with adequate clearance for its purpose
term.note: Lanes are often bounded by lane markings.
Lanes may be significantly wider than the normal vehicle width to allow variance in lane position of the vehicle as well as for various vehicle dimensions.
The "lane" nomenclature typically refers to motor vehicle usage, but can also refer to other purposes, such as sidewalks.
term.example: shoulder

term.name: lay-by
term.definition: short lane ( REF idDAF8D75AA574422cADE5F6D094406BB4 ) at the edge of a carriageway ( REF id855CC715739D462e9790E893914D8768 ) designed to allow a motor vehicle ( REF idC836FDA5C4344a98BC71F1C25FDC5A5E ) to temporarily stop while traffic in other lanes ( REF idDAF8D75AA574422cADE5F6D094406BB4 ) proceed

term.name: multi-carriageway
term.definition: roadway ( REF id3F880EDEBFE84014A43B46167936F4B1 ) comprised of more than two carriageways ( REF id855CC715739D462e9790E893914D8768 )
term.note: The separate carriageways are typically designed for separate traffic for (often multiple) specific operational reasons, such as direction of travel, category of vehicle (e.g., high occupancy vehicle), local versus through travel, etc.

term.name: reserved lane
term.definition: travel lane ( REF id1240152ED5B6429eA0A4B380F1D798E4 ) restricted to a specific subset of motor vehicles ( REF idC836FDA5C4344a98BC71F1C25FDC5A5E )
term.example: Bus lane
High-occupancy vehicle lane

term.name: roadside
term.definition: portion between one edge of the easement ( REF idF9F0ACCE2D49434a803C0D87211F753A ) and the closest edge of a carriageway ( REF id855CC715739D462e9790E893914D8768 )

term.name: roadway
term.definition: part of the easement ( REF idF9F0ACCE2D49434a803C0D87211F753A ) designed for use by motor vehicles ( REF idC836FDA5C4344a98BC71F1C25FDC5A5E )
term.note: Roadway relates to a cross-section of a road facility (i.e., zero length). See "road", "road section", "road segment", and "road link" for different types of stretches of roadway.

term.name: separation barrier
term.definition: barrier that separates carriageways ( REF id855CC715739D462e9790E893914D8768 )

term.name: shoulder
term.definition: lane ( REF idDAF8D75AA574422cADE5F6D094406BB4 ) between the edge of a carriageway ( REF id855CC715739D462e9790E893914D8768 ) and any slope or edge of right-of-way ( REF idF9F0ACCE2D49434a803C0D87211F753A )
term.note: The shoulder might be used for emergency stops or other purposes in addition to providing a clear zone and to promote ground stability at the edge of the carriageway.

term.name: single carriageway
term.definition: roadway ( REF id3F880EDEBFE84014A43B46167936F4B1 ) comprised of exactly one carriageway ( REF id855CC715739D462e9790E893914D8768 )

term.name: travel lane
term.definition: lane ( REF idDAF8D75AA574422cADE5F6D094406BB4 ) intended to allow motor vehicles ( REF idC836FDA5C4344a98BC71F1C25FDC5A5E ) to travel from one end of a road link ( REF idC615C2E3B7124c83B83FE649EAF6AD04 ) to the other

term.name: traveled way
term.definition: collection of all travel lanes of a carriageway

figure.name: road network terms

term.name: directional lanes
term.definition:
collection of all travel lanes ( REF id1240152ED5B6429eA0A4B380F1D798E4 ) of a road link ( REF idC615C2E3B7124c83B83FE649EAF6AD04 ) that are intended to allow travel in the same direction
Note 1 to entry: In actual use, an indication of the direction typically replaces the term "directional"
EXAMPLE 1 The eastbound lanes on a road
EXAMPLE 2 The north approach lanes at an intersection

term.name: directional lanes link
term.definition: collection of all lane links ( REF id71C155448DD245f68AFCA875F0884C00 ) of the same road link ( REF idC615C2E3B7124c83B83FE649EAF6AD04 ) and carriageway ( REF id855CC715739D462e9790E893914D8768 ) designed for travel in the same direction

term.name: lane link
term.definition: lane ( REF idDAF8D75AA574422cADE5F6D094406BB4 ) with starting and ending points that correspond to the starting and ending points of a road link ( REF idC615C2E3B7124c83B83FE649EAF6AD04 )

term.name: lane section
term.definition: complete sequential series of lane segments ( REF idE28C5D7863C84be78BBC6FDBB1153BBB ) within a road section ( REF id3A03AC4535C54232A92AD8E01B5AFDA0 )

term.name: lane segment
term.definition: complete sequential series of lane links ( REF id71C155448DD245f68AFCA875F0884C00 ) within a road segment ( REF idE86C320F77B445a18BB03478ACD8CBB2 )
term.note: A lane segment might start or end at locations other than the start or end of the corresponding road segment (e.g., a lane may start mid-block).
A lane segment only includes the sequential lane links, it does not include lane links from adjacent lanes.

term.name: road
term.definition: contiguous curvilinear length of the road network ( REF idEF0DB12C0BE247319EF2AC75AC234F8F ) that shares the same name
term.note: A length of the road network may be referenced by multiple names (e.g., Main Street and Route 7). In this case, there would be two "roads" that share the same set of "carriageways".
A road may turn at a junction.

term.name: road link
term.definition: contiguous length of a road segment ( REF idE86C320F77B445a18BB03478ACD8CBB2 ) that is described by the same set of physical characteristics
term.note: The definition of road segments is highly dependent on what characteristics are modelled by the implementation. Characteristics that might result in a new road segment include: addition or subtraction of a lane, a change in roadway width, the change of road type (e.g., start/end of a bridge), etc.

term.name: road network
term.definition: network of routes designed for the use of motor vehicles ( REF idC836FDA5C4344a98BC71F1C25FDC5A5E )

term.name: road section
term.definition: contiguous length of a road ( REF id72937CE094414775B90C995DFCB64EEB ) that shares the same management and operational characteristics
term.example: A traffic signal timing plan is applied to one road section.

term.name: road segment
term.definition: contiguous length of a road section ( REF id3A03AC4535C54232A92AD8E01B5AFDA0 ) bounded by a junction ( REF id6C52075FBEAD42d4B0FB9C8A7F8FD833 ), a jurisdictional boundary, a road section boundary, or a termination point at both ends

figure.name: junction terms

term.name: egress lane
term.definition: travel lane ( REF id1240152ED5B6429eA0A4B380F1D798E4 ) designed for exiting from a junction ( REF id6C52075FBEAD42d4B0FB9C8A7F8FD833 )

term.name: egress link
term.definition: directional lanes link ( REF id127FB835502F497a9F4FB2F5C4291560 ) representing all egress lanes ( REF idCC2F0AF206E94b6c811F65B1BC7B60A7 ) on a road link ( REF idC615C2E3B7124c83B83FE649EAF6AD04 )

term.name: ingress lane
term.definition: travel lane ( REF id1240152ED5B6429eA0A4B380F1D798E4 ) designed for entry into a junction ( REF id6C52075FBEAD42d4B0FB9C8A7F8FD833 )

term.name: ingress link
term.definition: directional lanes link ( REF id127FB835502F497a9F4FB2F5C4291560 ) representing all ingress lanes ( REF idA779A8E79A9446949679D6C81EA7934A ) on a road link ( REF idC615C2E3B7124c83B83FE649EAF6AD04 )

term.name: interchange
term.definition: junction ( REF id6C52075FBEAD42d4B0FB9C8A7F8FD833 ) where at least one movement is grade separated from all other movements
term.note: The concept of an interchange includes all movements at the junction, which may include multiple intersections.
The grade separation allows travelers on the link to pass unimpeded through the junction when congestion is not present.
term.example: A diamond interchange has two intersections.

term.name: intersection
term.definition: at-grade junction ( REF id6C52075FBEAD42d4B0FB9C8A7F8FD833 ), or a portion thereof, that is operated as a single entity
term.note: An at-grade junction of two dual carriageways would be considered a single intersection if right-of-way at the junction is determined by a single set of control logic (e.g., a traffic signal); however, such a junction could be operated as four distinct intersections, especially if the separation barriers were geographically large.

term.name: junction
term.definition: nexus where two or more roads meet in a manner that allows travellers to change roads
term.note: While the nexus is sometimes modelled as a point, it does in fact consume space

term.name: maneuver
term.definition: movement from an ingress lane ( REF idA779A8E79A9446949679D6C81EA7934A ) to an egress lane ( REF idCC2F0AF206E94b6c811F65B1BC7B60A7 )

figure.name: location terms

term.name: area location
term.definition:
location ( REF id3A8D97796CC142fa8882F36C623AA755 ) that has a two-dimensional character\r\n
\r\n

term.name: linear location
term.definition: location ( REF id3A8D97796CC142fa8882F36C623AA755 ) that has a one-dimensional character

term.name: location
term.definition: <font color="#313131">identifiable place within a three-dimensional space</font>
term.note: Within ITS, locations are typically locations on or near the surface of the earth.

term.name: point location
term.definition:
location ( REF id3A8D97796CC142fa8882F36C623AA755 ) that has a zero-dimensional character\r\n
\r\n

figure.name: location referencing terms

term.name: dynamic location reference
term.definition: location reference ( REF id0F23B7B6B1C64d828035A246CDCC780C ) generated on-the-fly based on geographic properties in a digital map database\r\n

term.name: link location
term.definition: pre-coded location reference ( REF id3A329C6B79D9436bA72E60C0685FE27D ) defined within the road network ( REF idEF0DB12C0BE247319EF2AC75AC234F8F ) database \r\n

term.name: location code
term.definition: identifier assigned to a location reference ( REF id0F23B7B6B1C64d828035A246CDCC780C )
term.note: A location code is often a numeric or alphanumeric identifier, but could be a textual name, symbol, or any other type of identifier.

term.name: location reference
term.definition: specification of a location ( REF id3A8D97796CC142fa8882F36C623AA755 ) according to a specific set of rules\r\n

term.name: location referencing
term.definition: method for referencing locations ( REF id3A8D97796CC142fa8882F36C623AA755 ) to facilitate the exchange of location related information between different systems\r\n

term.name: location table
term.definition: table of one or more entries that unambiguously defines a location ( REF id3A8D97796CC142fa8882F36C623AA755 ) according to a known set of conventions

term.name: pre-coded location reference
term.definition: location reference ( REF id0F23B7B6B1C64d828035A246CDCC780C ) using a unique identifier that is agreed upon in both sender and receiver system to select a location ( REF id3A8D97796CC142fa8882F36C623AA755 ) from a set of pre-coded locations\r\n

figure.name: Transport service

term.name: consumer
term.definition: <transport> consumer ( REF id8B698530E3B946b3B78C2E6C58FE87D7 ) that has a transport need ( REF id3B0C62628A72424e98B2D5C2F2BBCD36 ) to be fulfilled\r\n

term.name: item
term.definition: <transport> passenger and/or good

term.name: need
term.definition: <transport> need ( REF id8C060C793CE14fb88B50E52BD3A3FDE6 ) to transport one or more transport items to a different location

term.name: provider
term.definition: <transport> entity ( REF id040D6A1B412A4cc6921882357A58F747 ) that delivers one or more transport services ( REF id5F69F95814304a3991719C6E60838C0A )

term.name: service
term.definition: <transport> service ( REF id1C826F4DC7744eb7B8DDB33EF68A28F5 ) that delivers item(s) from one location to another on behalf of a transport consumer ( REF idE444860D95E5458a9BA4CF4BCE3EAD71 ) to satisfy a need ( REF id8C060C793CE14fb88B50E52BD3A3FDE6 )
term.note: The item(s) delivered might be people and/or goods.

figure.name: shared mobility

term.name: AV sharing
term.definition: using a shared AV service ( REF id84CD7C207A8D47c2B45CB2E6B7F15262 )

term.name: shared AV service
term.definition: shared mobility service ( REF id4522B42E3788443cAE5A47015FE4D41B ) where the on-board logic within the vehicle has the primary responsibility for the operation of the vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A )

term.name: shared mobility service
term.definition: transport service ( REF id5F69F95814304a3991719C6E60838C0A ) delivered by a transport provider ( REF idA3BC9C78F77A4be7BADD00079FED8167 ) that uses the same equipment and/or staff to provide transport services to multiple unrelated transport consumers ( REF idE444860D95E5458a9BA4CF4BCE3EAD71 )
term.note: A shared mobility service can be characterized by its contractual, financial, network, and operational models.

term.name: shared transport service
term.definition: shared mobility service ( REF id4522B42E3788443cAE5A47015FE4D41B ) where the transport provider ( REF idA3BC9C78F77A4be7BADD00079FED8167 ) has the primary responsibility for the selection and operation of the transport mode
term.note: A shared transport system might not be dependent upon a vehicle and/or could be multi-modal. For example, a letter courier service could rely on walking and public transport.

Responsibilities of the transport service might be further delegated to others. For example, a courier service relying on public transport would delegate the operation of the transport mode to the public transport operator.

term.name: shared vehicle service
term.definition: shared mobility service ( REF id4522B42E3788443cAE5A47015FE4D41B ) where the transport consumer ( REF idE444860D95E5458a9BA4CF4BCE3EAD71 ) has the primary responsibility for the operation of the vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A )
term.note: As there should only be one operator of a vehicle at any time, a shared vehicle service should use a sequential operational model.

This term can be specialized by replacing "vehicle" with any defined vehicle type; however, in some cases the the preferred form is to consolidate terms (e.g., "carsharing" rather than "passenger car sharing").

term.name: transport sharing
term.definition: using a shared transport service ( REF idAF252202FB50473fB51E56F3FBE6932E )

term.name: vehicle sharing
term.definition: using a shared vehicle service ( REF id8C73DE6A6FCF4643AE8C1A25A4E4C9CF )

figure.name: Contractual models

term.name: business-to-business
term.definition: <shared mobility> contractual model ( REF idB3582A5C7E9B4749A708EE0EECBCAC51 ) where the transport provider ( REF idA3BC9C78F77A4be7BADD00079FED8167 ) is a commercial entity or governmental agency and the transport consumer ( REF idE444860D95E5458a9BA4CF4BCE3EAD71 ) is a commercial entity
term.example: A business purchasing monthly public transport passes for its employees
A commercial entity using a commercial courier service for package delivery

term.name: business-to-consumer
term.definition: <shared mobility> contractual model ( REF idB3582A5C7E9B4749A708EE0EECBCAC51 ) where the transport provider ( REF idA3BC9C78F77A4be7BADD00079FED8167 ) is a commercial entity or governmental agency and the transport consumer ( REF idE444860D95E5458a9BA4CF4BCE3EAD71 ) is an individual

term.name: business-to-government
term.definition: <shared mobility> contractual model ( REF idB3582A5C7E9B4749A708EE0EECBCAC51 ) where the transport provider ( REF idA3BC9C78F77A4be7BADD00079FED8167 ) is a commercial entity or governmental agency and the transport consumer ( REF idE444860D95E5458a9BA4CF4BCE3EAD71 ) is a governmental entity
term.example: A governmental entity using a commercial courier service for package delivery

term.name: contractual model
term.definition: <shared mobility> legal framework used by a shared mobility service ( REF id4522B42E3788443cAE5A47015FE4D41B )\r\n
term.note: Contracts might be via a third party, implied or verbal, especially in the case of peer-to-peer.

term.name: peer-to-peer
term.definition: <shared mobility> contractual model ( REF idB3582A5C7E9B4749A708EE0EECBCAC51 ) where both the transport provider ( REF idA3BC9C78F77A4be7BADD00079FED8167 ) and the transport consumer ( REF idE444860D95E5458a9BA4CF4BCE3EAD71 ) are individuals
term.note: The two individuals may connect and/or contract through a thrid party service.
term.example: ridesourcing

figure.name: Financial models

term.name: commercial
term.definition: <shared mobility> financial model ( REF id1C9A28E75C534b08939F72CA1207904D ) where transport services ( REF id5F69F95814304a3991719C6E60838C0A ) are provided with a profit motive

term.name: cooperative
term.definition: <shared mobility> financial model ( REF id1C9A28E75C534b08939F72CA1207904D ) where transport consumers ( REF idE444860D95E5458a9BA4CF4BCE3EAD71 ) partner to defray the costs of transport services ( REF id5F69F95814304a3991719C6E60838C0A )
term.note: Cooperative models are exclusive commercial and public models.

term.name: financial model
term.definition: <shared mobility> economic framework used by a shared mobility service ( REF id4522B42E3788443cAE5A47015FE4D41B )

term.name: fractional ownership
term.definition: <shared mobility> cooperative ( REF idBF1211A2A721402c8450C76DD85215BD ) financial model where transport consumers ( REF idE444860D95E5458a9BA4CF4BCE3EAD71 ) partner to support the purchase, maintenance, and overhead costs associated with a vehicle

term.name: membership modifier
term.definition: <shared mobility> characteristic of a financial model ( REF id1C9A28E75C534b08939F72CA1207904D ) that indicates whether transport consumers ( REF idE444860D95E5458a9BA4CF4BCE3EAD71 ) are required to enter into a agreement prior to receiving transport services ( REF id5F69F95814304a3991719C6E60838C0A )

term.name: membership-based
term.definition: <shared mobility> characteristic of a financial model ( REF id1C9A28E75C534b08939F72CA1207904D ) that requires transport consumers ( REF idE444860D95E5458a9BA4CF4BCE3EAD71 ) to enter into a agreement prior to receiving transport services ( REF id5F69F95814304a3991719C6E60838C0A )
term.note: The agreement might be associated with fees.
The agreement might be minimal, such as collecting user information for business purposes.
The membership may be granted as a part of a broader agreement. For example, a university bus system might restrict access to students and faculty.

term.name: mutual benefit
term.definition: <shared mobility> cooperative ( REF idBF1211A2A721402c8450C76DD85215BD ) financial model where transport consumers ( REF idE444860D95E5458a9BA4CF4BCE3EAD71 ) partner on a per-trip basis

term.name: open-access
term.definition: <shared mobility> characteristic of a financial model ( REF id1C9A28E75C534b08939F72CA1207904D ) that does not require membership within an organization to receive transport services ( REF id5F69F95814304a3991719C6E60838C0A )
term.note: This includes models where membership is optional and might provide extra benefits.

term.name: public
term.definition: <shared mobility> financial model ( REF id1C9A28E75C534b08939F72CA1207904D ) where transport services ( REF id5F69F95814304a3991719C6E60838C0A ) are provided by an administrative authority in an attempt to better serve societal interests
term.note: The transport service is typically offered to the transport consumer for less than the full capital and operating cost of providing the service, but this is not a requirement.

Typically, the administrative authority is a local government agency; but it could be another administrative authority, such as the national government or a commercial entity managing transport needs on their campus.

figure.name: Operational models

term.name: concurrent
term.definition: <shared transport> operational model ( REF id9EE684356599469b905CF09986D497E9 ) where transport services ( REF id5F69F95814304a3991719C6E60838C0A ) might be provided to multiple transport consumers ( REF idE444860D95E5458a9BA4CF4BCE3EAD71 ) at any one time

term.name: dynamic route
term.definition: <shared transport> concurrent ( REF idE5D76E7905404edfBA6A94FCEC721A6A ) operation where transported items ( REF idA4530852939B41f89A9140C5CBE4D1A3 ) can only be received or delivered at stopping points within a pre-defined service corridor
term.note: The service corridor is defined by the provider, who may impose further restrictions on where stops are allowed.
The service corridor often includes a communal point of interest (e.g., an airport, transit hub, etc) as a fixed stopping point.
term.example: Airport shuttle

term.name: fixed route
term.definition: <shared transport> concurrent ( REF idE5D76E7905404edfBA6A94FCEC721A6A ) operation where transported items ( REF idA4530852939B41f89A9140C5CBE4D1A3 ) can only be received or delivered at stopping points contained in a pre-defined sequence
term.example: Traditional fixed-route bus line

term.name: operational model
term.definition: <shared transport> logistical framework used by a shared mobility service ( REF id4522B42E3788443cAE5A47015FE4D41B )
term.note: The logistical framework might set restrictions on how a passenger and/or good is received, transported, and/or delivered.

term.name: paired on-demand
term.definition: <shared transport> concurrent ( REF idE5D76E7905404edfBA6A94FCEC721A6A ) operation where the transport provider ( REF idA3BC9C78F77A4be7BADD00079FED8167 ) may choose to divert from its path to service a new request from another transport consumer ( REF idE444860D95E5458a9BA4CF4BCE3EAD71 ) while servicing an earlier transport consumer
term.example: ridesplitting

term.name: sequential
term.definition: <shared transport> operational model ( REF id9EE684356599469b905CF09986D497E9 ) where transport services ( REF id5F69F95814304a3991719C6E60838C0A ) are provided to a single transport consumer at any one time
term.note: A single transport consumer might request the transport of multiple passengers.
term.example: traditional taxi service

figure.name: Network models

term.name: free-floating one-way
term.definition: <shared mobility> network model ( REF id6CC6271D3BFF40d888883E5BC1C00632 ) where sharing may be initiated and terminated at any location meeting basic criteria
term.note: The basic criteria typically include geographic limits and requirements related to legal and safe locations.

term.name: network model
term.definition: <shared vehicle> infrastructure framework used by a shared mobility service ( REF id4522B42E3788443cAE5A47015FE4D41B )

term.name: station-based one-way
term.definition: <shared vehicle> operational mode ( REF id6CC6271D3BFF40d888883E5BC1C00632 ) where vehicle sharing ( REF id02140288CFE243579849576D93051804 ) is initiated and terminated at two different facilities managed by the transport provider ( REF idA3BC9C78F77A4be7BADD00079FED8167 )

term.name: station-based roundtrip
term.definition: <shared vehicle> operational mode ( REF id6CC6271D3BFF40d888883E5BC1C00632 ) where vehicle sharing ( REF id02140288CFE243579849576D93051804 ) is initiated and terminated at the same facility managed by the transport provider ( REF idA3BC9C78F77A4be7BADD00079FED8167 )

figure.name: transport service

term.name: carpool service
term.definition: rideshare service ( REF id6601C01283C840ef844C3A9CC99DB4EA ) that uses a passenger car ( REF idD4A825C9195540028C470BC2D3E25807 ) for transport

term.name: courier network service
term.definition: commercial ( REF id3AF823A8DE44425984FED140D4668259 ), peer-to-peer ( REF idABEF77BE95BA45a68CF387E17E03ED81 ) shared transport service ( REF idAF252202FB50473fB51E56F3FBE6932E ) that transports goods
term.note: The goods are typically small packages, letters, food, etc.

term.name: pedicab sevice
term.definition: taxi service ( REF id9C46F642683441229EE34B7ECD5FCF48 ) that uses a pedicycle ( REF id29D960837EC74ef5A4A17023C48287E8 ) to provide transport

term.name: rideshare service
term.definition: cooperative ( REF idBF1211A2A721402c8450C76DD85215BD ) shared transport service ( REF idAF252202FB50473fB51E56F3FBE6932E ) that transports passengers concurrently ( REF idE5D76E7905404edfBA6A94FCEC721A6A )

term.name: ridesourced service
term.definition: commercial ( REF id3AF823A8DE44425984FED140D4668259 ), peer-to-peer ( REF idABEF77BE95BA45a68CF387E17E03ED81 ) shared transport service ( REF idAF252202FB50473fB51E56F3FBE6932E ) that transports passengers

term.name: ridesplit service
term.definition: ridesourced service ( REF idF6E55203606D4d13BCD69D3349D0AE3B ) that serves passengers concurrently ( REF idE5D76E7905404edfBA6A94FCEC721A6A )

term.name: shuttle service
term.definition: shared transport service ( REF idAF252202FB50473fB51E56F3FBE6932E ) that transports passengers between two specified locations ( REF id3A8D97796CC142fa8882F36C623AA755 )
term.note: Each location might be defined as point, linear, or area locations; however, the areas of the two locations should not overlap.

term.name: taxi service
term.definition: commercial ( REF id3AF823A8DE44425984FED140D4668259 ) shared transport service ( REF idAF252202FB50473fB51E56F3FBE6932E ) that transports passengers sequentially ( REF idED3C7DDD53C34d7a87F9BF037CB98B16 )\r\n

term.name: taxi share service
term.definition: commercial ( REF id3AF823A8DE44425984FED140D4668259 ) shared transport service ( REF idAF252202FB50473fB51E56F3FBE6932E ) that transports passengers concurrently ( REF idE5D76E7905404edfBA6A94FCEC721A6A )

term.name: vanpool service
term.definition: rideshare service ( REF id6601C01283C840ef844C3A9CC99DB4EA ) that uses a passenger van ( REF id64B1872F39E1473cA68AED021CB6075F ) for transport

figure.name: vehicle sharing

term.name: bikesharing service
term.definition: shared vehicle service ( REF id8C73DE6A6FCF4643AE8C1A25A4E4C9CF ) that shares bicycles

term.name: carsharing service
term.definition: shared vehicle service ( REF id8C73DE6A6FCF4643AE8C1A25A4E4C9CF ) that shares passenger cars

figure.name: Mobility applications

term.name: B2C mobility sharing app
term.definition: mobility app ( REF id1C90ED2B61D74f899D6D199CB9A2B785 ) that assists a transport consumer ( REF idE444860D95E5458a9BA4CF4BCE3EAD71 ) in acquiring shared mobility services ( REF id4522B42E3788443cAE5A47015FE4D41B ) from a specific business

term.name: mobility app
term.definition: ITS-S application implementation ( REF id0FC1FF4E8B694277B63F2A0C167A0C87 ) designed to assist an individual transport consumer in understanding transport-related information, making decisions, and/or acting upon decisions

term.name: mobility fitness app
term.definition: mobility app ( REF id1C90ED2B61D74f899D6D199CB9A2B785 ) that tracks information about a traveller to provide health-related information \r\n
term.note: The information collected may include details such as speed, elapsed travel time, heart rate, etc.
The provided health information might include caloric consumption, peak heart rate, distance travelled, etc.

term.name: navigation app
term.definition: mobility app ( REF id1C90ED2B61D74f899D6D199CB9A2B785 ) that assists a transport consumer ( REF idE444860D95E5458a9BA4CF4BCE3EAD71 ) to determine the best route to the destination

term.name: P2P mobility sharing app
term.definition: mobility app ( REF id1C90ED2B61D74f899D6D199CB9A2B785 ) that assists a transport consumer ( REF idE444860D95E5458a9BA4CF4BCE3EAD71 ) in acquiring shared mobility services ( REF id4522B42E3788443cAE5A47015FE4D41B ) from an individual that participates in the mobility app's network

term.name: public transport app
term.definition: mobility app ( REF id1C90ED2B61D74f899D6D199CB9A2B785 ) that assists a transport consumer ( REF idE444860D95E5458a9BA4CF4BCE3EAD71 ) in using a public transport system
term.note: A public tranport app might include features such as viewing maps, searching routes and schedules, real-time arrival information, ticketing, electronic boarding pass, etc.

term.name: real-time traveller information app
term.definition: mobility app ( REF id1C90ED2B61D74f899D6D199CB9A2B785 ) that provides information about current travel conditions to a transport consumer ( REF idE444860D95E5458a9BA4CF4BCE3EAD71 )

term.name: ridesourcing app
term.definition: P2P mobility sharing app ( REF id04D43929B0A547e69C9315F341AFDC37 ) for acquiring a ridesourced service ( REF idF6E55203606D4d13BCD69D3349D0AE3B )

term.name: taxi hailing app
term.definition: mobility app ( REF id1C90ED2B61D74f899D6D199CB9A2B785 ) that assists a transport consumer ( REF idE444860D95E5458a9BA4CF4BCE3EAD71 ) in electronically requesting a taxi \r\n

term.name: trip aggregator app
term.definition: mobility app ( REF id1C90ED2B61D74f899D6D199CB9A2B785 ) that assists a transport consumer ( REF idE444860D95E5458a9BA4CF4BCE3EAD71 ) in planning trips that may span multiple vehicle modes or transport providers\r\n
term.note: The assistance might include reservations, ticketing, and similar services.

figure.name: Person - General terms

term.name: pedestrian
term.definition: vulnerable road user ( REF id2ED5E531BA0A4fe7BE47A4D2D284770D ) who is on foot

term.name: person
term.definition: entity, i.e. a natural or legal person, recognized by law as having legal rights and duties, able to make commitment(s), assume and fulfil resulting obligation(s), and able to be held accountable for its action(s)
term.note: Minimum and common external constraints applicable to a business transaction often require one to differentiate among three common sub-types of Person, namely "individual", "organization", and "public administration".
Person is capitalized to indicate that it is being utilized as formally defined in the standards and to differentiate it from its day-to-day use.
Synonyms for "legal person" include "artificial person", "body corporate", etc., depending on the terminology used in competent jurisdictions.

term.name: road user
term.definition: person ( REF idA195A5913A44427f96436DF49EAAC159 ) who is on or near a roadway ( REF id3F880EDEBFE84014A43B46167936F4B1 ) or in a vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A )

term.name: traveller
term.definition: person ( REF idA195A5913A44427f96436DF49EAAC159 ) who is headed to a destination

term.name: vulnerable road user
term.definition: road user ( REF id1F457ACEC814488eAAA90E21EA60F67F ) other than a vehicle occupant ( REF idEBD39D6495A4426d8293AE171A0D3899 )

figure.name: Person - Vehicle terms

term.name: driver
term.definition: person ( REF idA195A5913A44427f96436DF49EAAC159 ) who is operating a vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A )

term.name: passenger
term.definition: person ( REF idA195A5913A44427f96436DF49EAAC159 ) who has a reservation to travel or is travelling in a vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) except for any crew, staff, or drivers

term.name: vehicle occupant
term.definition: person ( REF idA195A5913A44427f96436DF49EAAC159 ) in a vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A )

figure.name: Physical objects - General terms

term.name: centre system
term.definition: ITS component ( REF id3783095C41E041c8B0CC1813CBCAEE44 ) that provides application, management, and/or administrative functions from a centralized location (i.e., not at the roadside ( REF id718D31DE1698436a9BA71D3F4512432A ))

term.name: field system
term.definition: ITS component ( REF id3783095C41E041c8B0CC1813CBCAEE44 ) that performs localized surveillance, traffic control, information provision, payment transaction, wireless communication services between mobile elements and fixed infrastructure, and/or other services.
term.note: Typically, field systems are located along the roadside.
Typically, the operation of field systems are governed by management functions running in centre systems.
term.example: traffic detector, camera, signal controller, message sign, tolling station

term.name: support system
term.definition: ITS component ( REF id3783095C41E041c8B0CC1813CBCAEE44 ) that provides support services for one or more other ITS components

term.name: traveller system
term.definition: ITS component ( REF id3783095C41E041c8B0CC1813CBCAEE44 ), other than a vehicle system ( REF id12A56C8A1EFE4cb8983C1C23C593EB84 ), that is used by a person in relation to a past, current, or upcoming journey

term.name: vehicle system
term.definition: ITS component ( REF id3783095C41E041c8B0CC1813CBCAEE44 ) that is installed as a component of a vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A )

figure.name: Centre terms

term.name: emergency management system
term.definition: centre system ( REF id75E3C9D3F2084e00BA93F5DD34084653 ) that allows an entity to manage and respond to crashes, events, disasters, evacuation orders, and other incidents

term.name: fleet and freight management system
term.definition: centre system ( REF id75E3C9D3F2084e00BA93F5DD34084653 ) that allows a fleet or freight operator to manage and control its personnel, equipment, and/or freight

term.name: maintenance and construction management system
term.definition: centre system ( REF id75E3C9D3F2084e00BA93F5DD34084653 ) that allows an entity to monitor and manage the construction and maintenance of roadway infrastructure

term.name: payment administration system
term.definition: centre system ( REF id75E3C9D3F2084e00BA93F5DD34084653 ) that allows an entity to manage financial transactions related to transportation, especially the electronic transfer of funds

term.name: public transport system
term.definition: centre system ( REF id75E3C9D3F2084e00BA93F5DD34084653 ) that allows an entity to manage the activities of a public transport agency

term.name: traffic management system
term.definition: centre system ( REF id75E3C9D3F2084e00BA93F5DD34084653 ) that monitors and controls traffic and the road network

term.name: traffic regulatory system
term.definition: centre system ( REF id75E3C9D3F2084e00BA93F5DD34084653 ) that officially records traffic regulations in electronic form so that they can be distributed to other systems

term.name: transport information system
term.definition: centre system ( REF id75E3C9D3F2084e00BA93F5DD34084653 ) that provides information of interest to the travelling public

figure.name: Field system term

term.name: field support equipment
term.definition: portable field system ( REF idC7D0D59CB4CF482c92AAA0D821A13A05 ) used by field personnel to locally troubleshoot, initialize, reprogram, and test infrastructure equipment

term.name: ITS roadway equipment
term.definition: field system ( REF idC7D0D59CB4CF482c92AAA0D821A13A05 ) that performs localized surveillance, traffic control, information provision, and/or payment transaction services

term.name: roadside equipment
term.definition: field system ( REF idC7D0D59CB4CF482c92AAA0D821A13A05 ) used to send electronic messages to and receive messages from nearby vehicle systems ( REF id12A56C8A1EFE4cb8983C1C23C593EB84 ) and traveller systems ( REF id3237352F30AA4cbeA2A9728C0671B5A4 ) via wireless technologies

term.name: roadside unit
term.definition: component of roadside equipment ( REF id5DAF919582BA4ebcA9458826C7601B83 ) that performs the logical control functions

figure.name: Support system terms

term.name: cooperative ITS credentials management system
term.definition: support system ( REF id23E6CD14703145869348FF4FB599A887 ) that enables trusted communications among ITS components and protects data from unauthorized access

term.name: map update system
term.definition: support system ( REF id23E6CD14703145869348FF4FB599A887 ) that provides map databases used to support ITS services ( REF id4D485872E9EE414e9CE1AB855A03540B )

figure.name: Traveller system terms

term.name: external in-vehicle device
term.definition: traveller system ( REF id3237352F30AA4cbeA2A9728C0671B5A4 ) consisting of GNSS and/or cellular modules that are connected to a vehicle during a trip\r\n

term.name: nomadic device
term.definition: personal information device ( REF id3E33A4D7FC4341d981D249AC28E47690 ) that is taken with and can be accessed by the traveller during a journey

term.name: personal information device
term.definition: traveller system ( REF id3237352F30AA4cbeA2A9728C0671B5A4 ) that enables personal access to traveller information
term.example: personal computer

term.name: public information device
term.definition: traveller system ( REF id3237352F30AA4cbeA2A9728C0671B5A4 ) that provides public access to traveller information
term.example: kiosk

figure.name: Vehicle system terms

term.name: commercial vehicle OBE
term.definition: vehicle OBE ( REF id19370BF79EB84485AEAD2DDF5F784F2F ) that provides functionality related to commercial vehicle operations

term.name: emergency vehicle OBE
term.definition: vehicle OBE ( REF id19370BF79EB84485AEAD2DDF5F784F2F ) that provides functionality related to emergency vehicle operations\r\n

term.name: public transport vehicle OBE
term.definition: vehicle OBE ( REF id19370BF79EB84485AEAD2DDF5F784F2F ) that provides functionality related to public transport vehicle operations

term.name: vehicle onboard equipment
term.definition: vehicle system ( REF id12A56C8A1EFE4cb8983C1C23C593EB84 ) that provides the onboard functions necessary to support the C-ITS services supported by the vehicle
term.note: It is preferred to include the word "vehicle" in the term so that it is sufficiently well distinguished from the specialized types of OBEs.

term.name: vehicle onboard unit
term.definition: component of vehicle onboard equipment ( REF id19370BF79EB84485AEAD2DDF5F784F2F ) that performs the logical control functions

figure.name: ITS station terms

term.name: ITS station
term.definition:
ITS component ( REF id3783095C41E041c8B0CC1813CBCAEE44 ) that provides a bounded secured managed domain ( REF id866BE3730A304564BBC18CA138D01808 ) and conforms to the ITS-S reference architecture ( REF idCAC31494A311430cBB567F2A82C166EC )
Note 1 to entry:
EDITOR’S NOTE 1 There appears to be ambiguity (and perhaps disagreement within the industry) as to whether a "bounded secured managed domain" is the logical domain within each ITS-S or if it represents the ITS-S network. The proposed definition uses the former concept.
EDITOR’S NOTE 2 The proposed definition assumes that an ITS-S does not cease being an ITS-S simply because it is disconnected from any network; therefore "in a communications network" is an invalid constraint.
EDITOR’S NOTE 3 As can be seen in a few examples, the phrase "network, comprised of applications…" is ambiguous as it is unclear if the ITS-S is comprised of the items or if the network is comprised of the items.
EDITOR’S NOTE 4 The proposed definition assumes that ITS-S are not required to have a wireless network interface. It is my understanding that any ITS device that conformed to the ITS-S architecture (which is almost a null requirement) and provides a BSMD (which is ill-defined) would be considered an ITS-S. Thus, at least at present, I see the term ITS-S to really mean any ITS physical entity that can claim to be secure (and it would be just a claim since there are no measurable requirements). And in fact, some definitions even make the BSMD optional – though I think this is wildly unwise.
EDITOR’S NOTE 5 Logically, an ITS-S seldom (if ever) provides ITS services because an ITS-S is a component of an ITS network; the ITS service is provided by the ITS as a whole. The ITS-S logically should provide ITS-S services, or more specifically, the ITS-S is comprised of the ITS-S architectural components (i.e., applications entity, facilities layer, etc), which all provide ITS-S services.
term.note: The ITS station architecture is defined in ISO 21217.

term.name: ITS-S unit
term.definition: implementation of an ITS station ( REF idF1E402D380EE478c957A2FF53D9EA0C5 )

figure.name: vehicle type terms

term.name: externally-propelled vehicle
term.definition: vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) propelled by an external entity\r\n
term.note: The external entity is often a self-propelled vehicle, but may be any external source, including and not limited to an animal (e.g., an ox pulling a cart), a cable (e.g., San Francisco Trolley cars), or magnets (e.g., a maglev train).

term.name: human-powered vehicle
term.definition: self-propelled vehicle ( REF idB08441BF9A294722835B3B7357A168C4 ) propelled by the muscular energy of one or more on-board person(s)\r\n

term.name: motor vehicle
term.definition: self-propelled vehicle ( REF idB08441BF9A294722835B3B7357A168C4 ) having at least two wheels, designed to be used on a road network, and propelled by an on-board motor\r\n

term.name: self-propelled vehicle
term.definition: vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) propelled by an on-board source\r\n
term.note: Contrast to externally propelled vehicle.

term.name: vehicle
term.definition: entity ( REF id040D6A1B412A4cc6921882357A58F747 ) used to transport people or physical goods\r\n

figure.name: Motor vehicles

term.name: bus
term.definition: passenger vehicle ( REF idF54BA07F34F947da99156CA6DC279B3B ) designed for the carriage of more than 15 passengers, whether seated or standing, in addition to the driver (if any)\r\n

term.name: goods vehicle
term.definition: motor vehicle ( REF idC836FDA5C4344a98BC71F1C25FDC5A5E ) with four or more wheels designed primarily for the carriage of goods per UNECE WP.29/1045\r\n
term.note: UNECE WP.29/1045 provides a formula to disambiguate between passenger vehicles (Category 1 vehicles) and goods vehicles (Category 2 vehicles).

term.name: moped
term.definition: motor vehicle ( REF idC836FDA5C4344a98BC71F1C25FDC5A5E ) with 2 or 3 wheels and a maximum design speed not exceeding 50 km/h\r\n

term.name: motorcycle
term.definition: motor vehicle ( REF idC836FDA5C4344a98BC71F1C25FDC5A5E ) with 2 or 3 wheels and a maximum design speed exceeding 50 km/h\r\n

term.name: passenger car
term.definition: passenger vehicle ( REF idF54BA07F34F947da99156CA6DC279B3B ) with not more than eight seating positions in addition to the driver’s seating position (if any) and not designed for standing passengers\r\n

term.name: passenger van
term.definition: passenger vehicle ( REF idF54BA07F34F947da99156CA6DC279B3B ) designed for the carriage of more than eight but fewer than 16 passengers, whether seated or standing, in addition to the driver (if any)\r\n

term.name: passenger vehicle
term.definition: motor vehicle ( REF idC836FDA5C4344a98BC71F1C25FDC5A5E ) with four or more wheels designed primarily for the carriage of (a) person(s)\r\n

figure.name: Human powered vehicles

term.name: bicycle
term.definition: human-powered vehicle ( REF id49A50B8238DB4306938080630FB05EEC ) with two wheels

term.name: pedicycle
term.definition: human-powered vehicle ( REF id49A50B8238DB4306938080630FB05EEC ) with two or more wheels \r\n

term.name: tricycle
term.definition: human-powered vehicle ( REF id49A50B8238DB4306938080630FB05EEC ) with three wheels

figure.name: Externally powered vehicles

term.name: carriage
term.definition: externally-propelled vehicle ( REF id9FB48FCCA5BD47288C38AFE544A2F3EC ) with more than two wheels propelled by an animal or person on foot\r\n

term.name: cart
term.definition: externally-propelled vehicle ( REF id9FB48FCCA5BD47288C38AFE544A2F3EC ) with two wheels propelled by an animal or person on foot\r\n

term.name: maglev vehicle
term.definition: externally-propelled vehicle ( REF id9FB48FCCA5BD47288C38AFE544A2F3EC ) that is levitated through the use of opposing magnets and propelled through the use of coordinated electro-magnets along a track

term.name: sidecar
term.definition: externally-propelled vehicle ( REF id9FB48FCCA5BD47288C38AFE544A2F3EC ) attached to a motorcycle ( REF id67B759675E174226A5272E7D8D7F6D93 )\r\n

term.name: trailer
term.definition: externally-propelled vehicle ( REF id9FB48FCCA5BD47288C38AFE544A2F3EC ) pulled by another vehicle

figure.name: Vehicle terms - Technology

term.name: automated vehicle
term.definition: vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) conforming to at least SAE J3016 Level 3 automation

term.name: conkditionally automated vehicle
term.definition: automated vehicle ( REF idA7CF87D985684eceB59879EF59C87184 ) conforming to SAE J3016 Level 3 driving automation

term.name: connected vehicle
term.definition: vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) that includes vehicle onboard equipment ( REF id19370BF79EB84485AEAD2DDF5F784F2F )

term.name: fully automated vehicle
term.definition: automated vehicle ( REF idA7CF87D985684eceB59879EF59C87184 ) conforming to SAE J3016 Level 5 driving automation

term.name: highly automated vehicle
term.definition: automated vehicle ( REF idA7CF87D985684eceB59879EF59C87184 ) conforming to SAE J3016 Level 4 driving automation

figure.name: Vehicle classifications

term.name: commercial vehicle
term.definition: vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) used for transporting goods or passengers for payment

term.name: heavy vehicle
term.definition: passenger van ( REF id64B1872F39E1473cA68AED021CB6075F ), bus ( REF idADB9CA402E854b5686121C1202A8AA6A ), or goods vehicle ( REF id5D915587849B43558A29C56430F62C03 )

term.name: public transport vehicle
term.definition: passenger van ( REF id64B1872F39E1473cA68AED021CB6075F ) or bus ( REF idADB9CA402E854b5686121C1202A8AA6A )

term.name: regulated vehicle
term.definition: vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) that is subject to special regulations based on the classification of the vehicle
